bio:
NatGeo Wildlife + Conservation Photojournalist + Speaker.
Next @NatGeo Live! Jan 19th, Park City, Utah

posts.caption:
@stevewinterphoto @africanparksnetwork @natgeo
Thank you to everyone who has donated on #GivingTuesday, we are close to our goal of $25,000! But if you haven’t given yet, there is still time. Your support is critical. Without our network of supporters, our Rangers would only be able to do a fraction of the work they do. Did you know rangers create pockets of peace in conflict-ridden zones, are providing security to 2.1 million people living in and around the parks we manage, and are the guardians for wildlife who cannot protect themselves? If you donate today, your gift to African Parks will go twice as far – because every dollar is being matched up to $25,000. And every dollar will go directly to the parks - where it’s needed most. Please click the link in our bio to donate to support our Rangers who a force for good. https://www.africanparks.org/giving-tuesday #AfricanParks #Rangers #ForceForGood #GivingTuesday #instagood #hope

@stevewinterphoto BIG CAT WEEKEND Nov 30th!!!!!
A cub in a tree who just saw mom.
November 30th 2018 is when #bigcatweekend kicks off in the USA! Please tune in to @natgeowild on the eve of the 30 November 21:00 to see our new show “Tree-Climbing Lions”. It tracks my adventures looking for incredible lions with @alexbraczkowski and @luke_ochse in southwestern Uganda. We’ll show you some incredible footage of lions balancing from the branches of 40 foot tall fig trees, wedged in the branches of cactus-like euphorbias and even hunting warthogs 🦁 Africa’s lions are in a state of decline across the majority of areas where they live. This is a unique story which tracks the lives of a unique population of lions with a culture of tree-climbing. It shows their behavior, their precarious existence in an increasingly human-dominated landscape and their conflict with cattle farmers 🐆
.

@stevewinterphoto @natgeo @africanparksnetwork - Zakouma Rangers coming in from 12 days in the field sitting with their friends who are getting ready to head out to protect the animals, people and ecosystem.
My goal today is to help @africanparksnetwork outfit their Rangers on #GivingTuesday. Many of you have asked how you can help save the species you see on my IG and on NG IG.
UPDATE: This Giving Tuesday, our goal is to raise $25,000. The outpouring of support has been incredible – thank you to everyone who has contributed so far. Each dollar donated today will be matched by a generous donor up to $25,000 - which means we could raise a total of $50,000. That’s enough to provide professional training to 25 new Rangers, developing the critical skills they need to do their jobs effectively!
We asked Aimee, one of our Rangers who lives and works in Garamba National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo why she does what she does. “So that my son and other children will always be able to see the animals in this park.” That’s a future we can all believe in. We hope you will take advantage of this Giving Tuesday opportunity and see your donation go twice as far. Every dollar counts. Please click on the link in our bio to donate today: https://www.africanparks.org/giving-tuesday#AfricanParks #Rangers #ForceForGood #GivingTuesday #instagood #hope

@stevewinterphoto @natgeo - Scientists trying to call in an injured lioness using animal calls at dusk in QE NP Uganda.
30 November 2018 is when #bigcatweekend kicks off in the USA! Please tune in to @natgeowild on the eve of the 2nd December to see our new show “Tree-Climbing Lions”. It tracks adventures looking for incredible lions with @alexbraczkowski and @luke_ochse in southwestern Uganda. We’ll show you some incredible footage of lions balancing from the branches of 40 foot tall fig trees, wedged in the branches of cactus-like euphorbias and even hunting warthogs Africa’s lions are in a state of decline across the majority of areas where they live. This is a unique story which tracks the lives of a unique population of lions with a culture of tree-climbing. It shows their behavior, their precarious existence in an increasingly human-dominated landscape and their conflict with cattle farmers. @natgeowild @natgeo

@stevewinterphoto @natgeo BIG CAT WEEKEND is Nov 30th!!!!!
A cub hiding in a tree. Looking at me.
November 30th 2018 is when #bigcatweekend kicks off in the USA! Please tune in to @natgeowild on the eve of the 2nd December to see our new show “Tree-Climbing Lions”. It tracks my adventures looking for incredible lions with @alexbraczkowski and @luke_ochse in southwestern Uganda. We’ll show you some incredible footage of lions balancing from the branches of 40 foot tall fig trees, wedged in the branches of cactus-like euphorbias and even hunting warthogs 🦁 Africa’s lions are in a state of decline across the majority of areas where they live. This is a unique story which tracks the lives of a unique population of lions with a culture of tree-climbing. It shows their behavior, their precarious existence in an increasingly human-dominated landscape and their conflict with cattle farmers 🐆
.

@stevewinterphoto for @africanparksnetwork
Mike Toft above is a wildlife veterinarian getting the drugs ready to tranquilize a group of lions to be relocated to another AP Park where they have been poached out. Mike is part of the team that makes it all work! Community is vitally important - here - rangers come in from being out in the field for 12 days - while others are getting ready to leave. These men and women are brothers and sisters - cousins - neighbors. They all have a important link to protecting the park it’s wildlife and the people - their family and neighbors that live within.
Rangers are often the first, and last line of defense not just in protecting the world’s wildlife, but in providing safety for millions of people around the world. Here in Zakouma National Park in Chad, after a devastating eight years where poaching reduced the elephant population from 4,000 to 400, the rangers are doing more than just holding the line. In 2010 in partnership with the Chadian Government, conservation organization African Parks @africanparksnetwork assumed management of the park and overhauled law enforcement. It wasn’t for the faint of heart. Just a year after cracking down on poaching, six rangers were killed by poachers during their morning prayers before going out on patrol. But the rangers persevered and continued in their fight to protect the Park, its wildlife, and the surrounding communities. Eight years later, poaching has essentially become non-existent. Employment is on the rise, thousands of children are going to schools built by the park, and tourism is booming.
Rhinos were even reintroduced after a 50-year absence just in May, and elephants are on the rise for the first time in a decade. A record number of elephant calves were recently counted - showing new life and hope has been restored to Zakouma, thanks to the rangers. To follow these ranger stories, please visit @africanparksnetwork who has the largest ranger force in Africa.
#AfricanParks #WorldRangerDay #Zakouma #Elephants #hope #gratitude #intheirshoes #outfitaranger

Video by @alexbraczkowski and @stevewinterphoto
If you’ve had a rough week, here is a shot of a big male lion taking a wee up in a tree 40 feet off the ground! Catch “Tree-climbing lions” this Friday in the USA on @natgeowild 🦁if you’re in Australia it is tomorrow night at 20:00, Hong Kong and Indonesia it is also tomorrow evening on @natgeowild 🙏 the show tracks the lives of two prides of tree-climbing lions in Uganda, the threats they face and an important new count being implemented to learn more about their populations! I’m in the film covering a daring operation of a lioness being saved from a poachers snare! Please tune in and let me know what you think! 🦁🦁🦁
